title: R44393
content: A standard of identity establishes the composition of a food, including mandatory and optional ingredients, and fixes the amounts or relative proportions of each ingredient or a specific method of manufacture. Congress intended that standards of identity would resemble "recipes" for specific foods to prevent economic adulteration and mislabeling. Section 401 of the FFDCA gives the FDA authority to create these standards to ensure consumers receive what they expect. The FDA has the authority to establish standards of identity for food through regulations to promote honesty and fair dealing for consumers. These standards define the composition, quality, and fill of containers for each food product, ensuring that products meet the specified requirements. The FDA establishes standards of identity for food to ensure honesty and fair dealing for consumers. Products must meet composition requirements set by the FDA to be marketed under a specific name. The FDA deems a food misbranded if it deviates from the established standard of identity. The Nutrition Labeling and Education Act allows for the addition of safe ingredients to standardized foods. Under the Nutrition Labeling and Education Act, FDA regulations allow for safe ingredients to be added to standardized foods, enabling manufacturers to use modified versions of traditional foods to meet nutritional goals while maintaining a descriptive name. The FDA allows for modified versions of traditional standardized foods to meet nutritional goals while maintaining a descriptive name. This flexibility in food regulation encourages oversight without affecting food characteristics and minimizes the need for future amendments. The FDA also follows food standards set by the Codex Alimentarius Commission. The FDA adopts food standards from the Codex Alimentarius Commission, promoting food safety. These standards are published in the Federal Register for public review before acceptance. Congress authorized the promulgation of food identity standards in 1938. The Pure Food and Drugs Act of 1906 did not give the government legal authority to set food standards, leading to limited oversight of "imitation" products. In the 1920s and 1930s, the government filed claims against a product called "Bred Spred" for misbranding under the 1906 act. The product contained 20% fruit but did not meet the 45% fruit content standard for jam. The manufacturer argued that Bred Spred was not misbranded as it did not claim to be jam. The courts ruled that Bred Spred, a product with 20% fruit content, was not misbranded under the 1906 act as it did not claim to be jam. Congress was concerned about such products leading to fraud and loss of consumer confidence, prompting the passage of the 1938 act. The FDA promulgates food identity standards through a three-stage rulemaking process. The FDA follows a three-stage rulemaking process to establish standards of identity for food. Interested parties can propose a standard of identity through a citizen petition, providing reasonable grounds to demonstrate how it would benefit consumers. The petitioner must commit to supporting the proposal with additional evidence. The FDA requires citizen petitioners to promote honesty and fair dealing in the interest of consumers. If the proposal meets requirements, it is published in the Federal Register for public comments. The agency can then decide to reject or accept the proposal through an order, with no specific timeframe for issuance. The FDA can reject or accept a proposal by publishing an order, with no specific timeframe for issuance. The order establishes the standard of identity and becomes effective on the specified date. Within 30 days, the agency enters the second stage of the rulemaking process, where objections can be submitted, leading to a public evidentiary hearing to resolve disputed issues. The filing of objections results in a stay of the disputed provisions until final FDA action is taken. The FDA conducts a public hearing where participants can present evidence and testimony, cross-examine witnesses, and object to a proposed order. The agency then issues a final order setting forth the standard of identity. Any party of record can object to the proposed order and request an oral argument before the FDA. The FDA publishes the final order establishing the standard of identity, which can be judicially reviewed by parties adversely affected. Judicial review can be sought in the U.S. Court of Appeals, where the court has the authority to affirm or set aside the order. The FDA's findings on the standard of identity order can be judicially reviewed by parties affected, allowing the court to affirm or set aside the order based on substantial evidence. This scope of judicial review is appropriate for regulations adopted by administrative agencies. The Supreme Court's scope of judicial review for regulations of general application by administrative agencies was affirmed in Federal Security Administrator v. Quaker Oats Co. The Court reviewed the FDA's authority to set standards of identity for various flour mill products, with the Seventh Circuit initially setting aside these standards. The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit set aside the standards of identity for farina and enriched farina, stating the evidence was speculative. The Supreme Court upheld the standards, emphasizing that courts cannot override agency decisions under the FFDCA. The Supreme Court upheld the standards of identity for farina and enriched farina, stating that courts cannot substitute their judgment for that of the agency. The Court deferred to the Administrator's judgment, concluding that there was sufficient evidence to support the standards and prevent consumer confusion. The Supreme Court upheld agency determinations on standards of identity, stating that if based on substantial evidence and within legal limits, it is controlling. To amend or remove a standard, the agency follows formal rulemaking procedures, including filing a petition for changes. Amendments may allow new ingredients or manufacturing methods. The FDA enforces standards of identity through the misbranding provision in the FFDCA. If a food is deemed misbranded, the agency can take enforcement actions against the manufacturer. The FDA enforces standards of identity through the misbranding provision in the FFDCA. A food is deemed misbranded if it does not conform to the prescribed definition and standard of identity, and its label does not bear the specified name of the food and common names of optional ingredients. Courts interpret "purport" broadly to challenge food that resembles a standard of identity without requiring evidence of consumer deception. For example, the U.S. government took enforcement action against food sold as "tomato catsup." The court does not require evidence of consumer deception under the misbranding provision. The U.S. government took action against food labeled as "tomato catsup with preservative" for not meeting the standard of identity for catsup. The Second Circuit ruled that the product still "purports to be tomato catsup" despite the addition of a preservative. The court ruled that a product labeled as "tomato catsup with preservative" violated the standard of identity for catsup, and thus was misbranded. The FDA has discretion in enforcing misbranding provisions for standards of identity. The FDA can enforce misbranding provisions for standards of identity under Section 403(g) of the FFDCA by issuing warning letters to alleged violators. Warning letters are informal and advisory, conveying the FDA's position without committing to further enforcement action. These letters are not considered final agency actions subject to judicial review. The FDA issues warning letters for minor violations of the act to give recipients a chance to take corrective actions before formal enforcement. This is considered a more efficient enforcement option when prompt corrective action is expected from the responsible parties. The FDA may issue a warning letter as an efficient enforcement option for minor violations, expecting prompt corrective action. Seizure of misbranded food in interstate commerce is another enforcement action under the FFDCA to protect public health. The FDA can seize adulterated or misbranded food to protect public health. The U.S. district court has jurisdiction over the seizure proceeding, which may result in the condemnation and destruction of the seized food.
